items.content: The Government says the tool will help ‘more accurately estimate the financial impact of adopting a fully bulk-billing model’.

ai_summary: The Australian government launched a new bulk-billing calculator for healthcare providers.
The tool aims to help estimate the financial impact of fully bulk-billing patients.
The government hopes the calculator will encourage more bulk-billing practices.
The calculator provides data to help healthcare providers make informed decisions.
The tool is part of a broader effort to improve healthcare affordability.

clusters.title: Is it true that … doing puzzles prevents dementia?
clusters.neutral_headline: Is it true that … doing puzzles prevents dementia?: Completing a fiendish jigsaw certainly engages many areas of the brain, but genetics and other lifestyle factors also play their part‘That’s a very strong statement,” cautions Roxi Carare, professor of clinical neuroanatomy at the University of Southampton. “A more appropriate way to put it is: puzzles help delay the onset and worsening of the symptoms of dementia.”Dementia is an umbrella term for conditions that lead to a decline in cognitive function. Some kinds have been linked to poor waste removal from the brain. Continue reading

items.title: Is it true that … doing puzzles prevents dementia?

Some kinds have been linked to poor waste removal from the brain. Continue reading...
items.content: Completing a fiendish jigsaw certainly engages many areas of the brain, but genetics and other lifestyle factors also play their part‘That’s a very strong statement,” cautions Roxi Carare, professor of clinical neuroanatomy at the University of Southampton. “A more appropriate way to put it is: puzzles help delay the onset and worsening of the symptoms of dementia.”Dementia is an umbrella term for conditions that lead to a decline in cognitive function. Some kinds have been linked to poor waste removal from the brain. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Puzzles engage the brain but do not necessarily prevent dementia.
Genetics and other lifestyle factors also influence dementia risk.
Puzzles may help delay the onset and worsening of dementia symptoms.
Dementia is a group of conditions causing cognitive decline.
Some dementia types are linked to poor brain waste removal.

The article explores the impact of rising costs on individuals using these medications.

clusters.title: States rally to offset fracturing of federal healthcare agencies: ‘Diseases don’t see state lines’
clusters.neutral_headline: States collaborate to offset federal healthcare agency changes

items.title: States rally to offset fracturing of federal healthcare agencies: ‘Diseases don’t see state lines’
items.standfirst: Changes to regulatory or information environments will help states decouple from federal health recommendationsSeven US states and the nation’s largest city announced this week that they have formed the Northeast Public Health Collaborative, in an effort to strengthen the region’s health guidance as the national health landscape fractures. Maryland announced they would join the alliance on Friday.As national health agencies revisit their recommendations, including high-profile restrictions on the updated Covid shots and the measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV) vaccine, the pressure is increasingly falling on states to navigate recommendations and new federal rules. Continue reading...
items.content: Changes to regulatory or information environments will help states decouple from federal health recommendationsSeven US states and the nation’s largest city announced this week that they have formed the Northeast Public Health Collaborative, in an effort to strengthen the region’s health guidance as the national health landscape fractures. Maryland announced they would join the alliance on Friday.As national health agencies revisit their recommendations, including high-profile restrictions on the updated Covid shots and the measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV) vaccine, the pressure is increasingly falling on states to navigate recommendations and new federal rules. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Seven US states and New York City formed a health collaborative.
The Northeast Public Health Collaborative aims to strengthen regional health guidance.
States are navigating recommendations and new federal rules.
National health agencies are revisiting recommendations, including vaccine restrictions.
Maryland announced joining the alliance on Friday.

clusters.title: How modern life makes us sick – and what to do about it
clusters.neutral_headline: Modern life's impact on health and well-being explored

items.title: How modern life makes us sick – and what to do about it
items.standfirst: From depression to obesity, the concept of ‘evolutionary mismatch’ can help foster self-compassion and point the way to a more rewarding existenceOne of the fascinating things about working as a psychotherapist is the opportunity to observe how many of our problems involve us getting in the way of ourselves. The difficulties we encounter are frequently the result of self-sabotage, and managing them often requires wrestling with our own drives, doing our best not to give in to every impulse. This is easier said than done, of course. To lose weight and keep it off, to successfully climb out of debt, to find meaningful work, to maintain long-term, happy relationships: all demand postponing our immediate desires in the service of a longer-term goal.Delaying gratification, as it’s called, has been a useful tactic for aeons. But at a certain point it becomes reasonable to ask: why does so much of modern life seem to involve swimming upstream? Why is it that following our instincts often seems to land us in so much trouble? Continue reading...
items.content: From depression to obesity, the concept of ‘evolutionary mismatch’ can help foster self-compassion and point the way to a more rewarding existenceOne of the fascinating things about working as a psychotherapist is the opportunity to observe how many of our problems involve us getting in the way of ourselves. The difficulties we encounter are frequently the result of self-sabotage, and managing them often requires wrestling with our own drives, doing our best not to give in to every impulse. This is easier said than done, of course. To lose weight and keep it off, to successfully climb out of debt, to find meaningful work, to maintain long-term, happy relationships: all demand postponing our immediate desires in the service of a longer-term goal.Delaying gratification, as it’s called, has been a useful tactic for aeons. But at a certain point it becomes reasonable to ask: why does so much of modern life seem to involve swimming upstream? Why is it that following our instincts often seems to land us in so much trouble? Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses how modern life contributes to health issues.
The concept of "evolutionary mismatch" is explored in relation to health.
The article suggests ways to foster self-compassion.
The author is a psychotherapist observing patient struggles.
The article explores the challenges of delaying gratification in modern life.

clusters.title: For years I struggled with infertility and loss. Then I had a life-changing call with a psychic
clusters.neutral_headline: For years I struggled with infertility and loss. Then I had a life-changing call with a psychic:

items.title: For years I struggled with infertility and loss. Then I had a life-changing call with a psychic
items.standfirst: On some level, I realised it was a bit unhinged, writes the author and podcaster Elizabeth Day. But what did I have to lose? On 29 December 2022, I received a text. ‘Hi mum I’m texting you off a friends phone I’ve smashed mine and their phones about to die, can you WhatsApp my new number x’ I was in a rental car when I got it, my partner at the wheel next to me as we drove down an anonymous stretch of motorway. Both the sky and the road were grey. It was that indeterminate space between Christmas and New Year when the days become sludgy and diffuse; a time when teenagers meet up with their friends to go shopping or gather in each other’s homes and post Snapchats or exchange festive gossip while pretending not to vape. It was the time of waiting – for the next thing to happen, for the promised excitement of New Year’s Eve and snogging underneath leftover mistletoe. So it wasn’t a particularly unusual text to receive, especially not given the trademark adolescent lack of grammar and punctuation.There was just one thing. Continue reading...
items.content: On some level, I realised it was a bit unhinged, writes the author and podcaster Elizabeth Day. But what did I have to lose? On 29 December 2022, I received a text. ‘Hi mum I’m texting you off a friends phone I’ve smashed mine and their phones about to die, can you WhatsApp my new number x’ I was in a rental car when I got it, my partner at the wheel next to me as we drove down an anonymous stretch of motorway. Both the sky and the road were grey. It was that indeterminate space between Christmas and New Year when the days become sludgy and diffuse; a time when teenagers meet up with their friends to go shopping or gather in each other’s homes and post Snapchats or exchange festive gossip while pretending not to vape. It was the time of waiting – for the next thing to happen, for the promised excitement of New Year’s Eve and snogging underneath leftover mistletoe. So it wasn’t a particularly unusual text to receive, especially not given the trademark adolescent lack of grammar and punctuation.There was just one thing. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author received a text message on December 29, 2022.
The text was from someone claiming to be her child.
The author was in a rental car at the time of the text.
The author was driving between Christmas and New Year.
The author was unsure of the text's authenticity.

clusters.title: I had a stroke during an ocean swim. Most people passed by unaware. One didn’t
clusters.neutral_headline: I had a stroke during an ocean swim. Most people passed by unaware. One didn’t:

items.title: I had a stroke during an ocean swim. Most people passed by unaware. One didn’t
items.standfirst: When Graham Russell set out for a dip in powerful wintry surf, he had no idea the beach where he had helped save lives as a surf lifesaver would become the place where his own was changedIt was an exhilarating day in every possible way. Standing on the cold sand on a Sunday morning, I saw the sun flash off powerful surf as it curved into whitewater that rushed up the beach. The sound of it boomed around the nearby cliffs. The passing clouds threw dark green patches across the frothy water, the air was crisp and dry. Today’s swim promised to be great.The members of my winter swimming club were pulling on cozzies, bright pink swimming caps and goggles as they assessed the challenging conditions. The car park was jammed with surfers from all around. Word had spread that MacMasters beach here on the New South Wales Central Coast was the place to experience this monstrous east swell.Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads Continue reading...

The passing clouds threw dark green patches across the frothy water, the air was crisp and dry. Today’s swim promised to be great.The members of my winter swimming club were pulling on cozzies, bright pink swimming caps and goggles as they assessed the challenging conditions. The car park was jammed with surfers from all around. Word had spread that MacMasters beach here on the New South Wales Central Coast was the place to experience this monstrous east swell.Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads Continue reading...

ai_summary: Graham Russell had a stroke during an ocean swim.
The swim took place in powerful wintry surf.
The beach was where he had previously saved lives.
The article details the experience of having a stroke.
The article highlights the role of a person who noticed the stroke.
